<dialogue>
P: Hey, doc! *giggles* I'm so glad I'm finally here. I feel like I've been waitin' forever!
D: Hi there, Maria! Nice to see you too. How's your asthma been lately?
P: Honestly, it's been kinda bad. I get really winded during volleyball practice, and my coach is gettin' on my case 'cause I'm slowin' everyone down.
D: I see. And how long has this been goin' on for?
P: Um, a few weeks now? I don't know, maybe a month?
D: Okay. Have you been using your inhaler as prescribed?
P: Yeah, I try to, but sometimes I forget or I don't wanna be seen takin' it in front of my friends.
D: I understand. It's good that you're tryin' to manage your symptoms on your own, but it's also super important to use your inhaler regularly to keep your asthma under control. Can you tell me more about these episodes of shortness of breath? How long do they last?
P: Like, they come on sudden, and I can barely catch my breath for like, a minute or two? It's really scary, doc.
D: I'm so sorry you're feelin' that way, sweetie. It's not fun at all. Have you noticed any triggers that might be causin' these episodes?
P: Um, no... I don't think so? I mean, I'm not around any smoke or pollen or anything like that.
D: Okay. We'll need to do some tests to figure out what's goin' on. I'm gonna prescribe you a new inhaler that's a bit stronger, and I want you to use it every day, even if you don't feel like you need it. Can you do that for me?
P: Yeah... I guess so. I just don't wanna be held back from doin' stuff I love, you know?
D: I totally get it, Maria. And we're gonna work together to make sure you can keep doin' the things you love without worryin' about your asthma. Alright?
P: Okay... thanks, doc.
D: Anytime, sweetie. Now, let's talk about your mom and how she's doin' with your asthma. How's she been helpin' you out?
P: Oh, she's been great! She reminds me to take my meds, and she's always there to support me when I'm feelin' down.
D: That's wonderful. It's great that you have such a supportive family. I'm gonna give your mom a call to let her know what we're doin' and to make sure she's on board with the new treatment plan.
P: Okay, that's cool. I'm just glad I can get back to practice and not be held back no more.
D: Absolutely, Maria. We're gonna get you back on track in no time.
P: Thanks again, doc!
D: Anytime, sweetie. Now, let's get that prescription filled and get you set up with the new inhaler, okay?
P: Sounds good to me!
</dialogue>

<dialogue>
P: Hey, doc. My asthma's been acting up lately. I get winded super fast on the skatepark.
D: Okay, Mateo, let's take a closer look at your symptoms. When did you first notice this increase in shortness of breath?
P: Um... I don't know. Maybe a month ago? I just kinda started feeling tired all the time.
D: And have you been taking your inhalers regularly?
P: Yeah, I have. My mom reminds me every morning and before I go to the skatepark.
D: That's good. Now, I want to check your peak flow. Can you breathe into this thing?
P: (takes a deep breath, blows into the peak flow meter) Like this?
D: Perfect. Now, let's take a look at the results. (examines the meter) Hmmm... it looks like your peak flow is a bit lower than it should be.
P: What does that mean?
D: It means we might need to adjust your medication or maybe even add a new inhaler to your routine.
P: Oh, okay. I don't wanna be on more meds than I need to be.
D: I understand your concern, Mateo. But we need to make sure your symptoms don't get worse. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? When do they happen, and how long do they last?
P: They happen when I'm skating or playing sports. And they last... I don't know... a few minutes? Until I take my inhaler.
D: And have you noticed any triggers that might be setting off your symptoms?
P: Triggers? Um... I think it might be the cold air? Or maybe the exercise itself?
D: That's a good start. We can work on identifying triggers and finding ways to manage them. But first, let's talk about your current medication. Are you taking the inhaler as prescribed?
P: Yeah, I am. But I sometimes forget to take it when I'm really busy.
D: Okay. Well, let's try to find ways to make it easier for you to remember. Maybe we can set reminders on your phone or something.
P: That's a good idea, doc. Thanks.
D: No problem, Mateo. Now, I want to prescribe you a new inhaler that might help you breathe easier. And I want to schedule a follow-up appointment to check on your progress.
P: Okay, sounds good. Thanks, doc.
D: You're welcome, Mateo. Just remember to take your medication as prescribed and come back and see me in a few weeks, okay?
P: Got it. Will do.
D: And one more thing... I want you to try to avoid exercising in really cold air for a while. Can you do that for me?
P: Yeah, I can do that. I'll just skate in the sun or something.
D: That's perfect. And if you ever feel like your symptoms are getting worse, don't hesitate to call me, okay?
P: Okay, doc. Thanks again.
D: Anytime, Mateo. Take care of yourself, okay?
P: Will do. Bye, doc.
</dialogue>

<dialogue>
P: Mom said I gotta come back here 'cause my asthma's been acting up.
D: That's right, Diego. We need to check in on your asthma management. Can you tell me a little bit about what's been going on?
P: I dunno... I just get winded easy when I'm skateboarding with my friends. And sometimes I feel like I'm gonna pass out.
D: I see. And when was the last time you had an episode like that?
P: Um... yesterday? We were at the skate park and I had to stop and sit down for a bit.
D: Okay, Diego. I want to review your inhaler use with you. Are you using your albuterol as prescribed?
P: Yeah... I think so... Mom reminds me, but sometimes I forget.
D: It's easy to forget, but it's really important to use it consistently. Can you tell me about your symptoms when you're using the inhaler? Do you feel like it's helping?
P: It does, but it's not like it's working super fast. It takes a few minutes to kick in.
D: That's good to know. I want to make sure we're not missing anything. Have you been keeping track of your peak flow readings?
P: Uh... no... I don't think so... Mom's supposed to do it, but she's been busy.
D: Okay, well we'll need to work on that. Can you tell me about your exercise routine? Are you doing any strenuous activities without your inhaler?
P: No, I'm not stupid... I know I gotta use it when I'm exercising. But sometimes my friends just wanna go, you know?
D: I understand. It's hard to keep up with friends sometimes. But safety first, Diego. We need to make sure you're managing your asthma properly. Can you tell me about your diet? Are you eating any foods that might trigger your asthma?
P: Um... I don't think so... Mom's been trying to get me to eat healthier, but I like junk food.
D: Okay, well we'll talk about that later. For now, let's focus on your asthma. I want to prescribe you a new inhaler that's a bit easier to use. Would you be okay with that?
P: Yeah... I guess so... If it's better, I'm down.
D: Great. And I want you to start tracking your peak flow readings, okay? That way we can make sure your asthma is under control.
P: Okay... I'll try... I mean, I'll do it.
D: Good. I'll also prescribe you some medication to help with your symptoms. And I want you to schedule regular follow-ups with me to check in on your asthma.
P: Okay... I'll tell Mom.
D: Great. And one more thing, Diego. I want you to talk to your friends about your asthma. It's not something to be ashamed of. It's something to be managed, and with the right tools, you can live a normal life.
P: Yeah... I guess you're right... I just feel like I'm a bother sometimes.
D: You're not a bother, Diego. You're a kid who needs to take care of himself. And that's okay. We'll get through this together, okay?
P: Yeah... okay.
</dialogue>

He worries that these symptoms might affect his academic performance or reputation as someone reliable. Nonetheless, Eli finds genuine happiness in the small rituals of family dinners, finishing new books, and connecting with people who understand his quirky sense of humor. His greatest strengths are empathy and resilience, while his tendency to overthink and self-doubt can hold him back at times.

<dialogue>
P: Hi, Dr. Patel. Thanks for seeing me again.
D: Hi Eli, of course. What brings you in today?
P: Just, you know, my mom wanted to make sure I'm doing okay with these headaches. They've been pretty bad lately.
D: I see. And how often have you been getting them?
P: Um, like, at least once a week, I'd say. Sometimes they're pretty mild, but other times they're super bad and I just want to go to bed.
D: I understand. Can you tell me more about what happens when you get a headache? Do you see any visuals or experience any other symptoms?
P: Yeah, sometimes I get this weird, zigzaggy line in my vision, and it makes me feel really nauseous. And my head just throbs, you know?
D: That sounds really uncomfortable. Have you been keeping a headache journal or tracking when they happen?
P: Not really... I mean, I've tried to, but it's hard to remember when they happen. My mom says I should, but I just forget.
D: That's okay. We can work on that. Have you noticed any triggers that might be contributing to these headaches?
P: Triggers? Um, I think maybe it's when I'm really stressed out or when I'm playing basketball and I get really sweaty. But that's just a guess.
D: That's a good start. We can explore those possibilities further. In the meantime, I'd like to prescribe you a triptan to help manage the pain. Would you be okay with that?
P: Yeah, sure. I just want to feel better, you know?
D: Of course, Eli. And just to reassure you, these headaches are not a sign of anything more serious. We just need to figure out how to manage them so they don't interfere with your daily life.
P: Okay... that makes me feel a little better, I guess.
D: Good. Now, let's talk about some lifestyle changes we can make to help prevent these headaches. Have you been getting enough sleep and eating regular meals?
P: Um, not really... I mean, I try to, but it's hard to get up early for breakfast sometimes.
D: Okay. We can work on establishing a better sleep schedule and meal routine. And have you been exercising regularly?
P: Yeah, I play basketball, but I don't really do any other exercise.
D: That's great that you're active! We can encourage you to do some stretching and yoga to help reduce stress and prevent headaches.
P: Okay, that sounds good, I guess.
D: Eli, I want you to know that you're not alone in this. We'll work together to find a solution that works for you. And don't forget, your parents are here to support you too.
P: Yeah... thanks, Dr. Patel. I feel a little better now.
D: That's what I'm here for, Eli. Now, let's schedule a follow-up appointment for a few weeks from now to check in on your progress.
P: Okay, sounds good.
D: Great. And Eli, just one more thing: it's okay to take care of yourself and ask for help when you need it. You don't have to be the strong, silent type all the time.
P: (laughs) Yeah, I guess not.
D: (laughs) Exactly. Now, I'll prescribe you the triptan and we'll get you set up with a better routine. Sound good?
P: Yeah, sounds good.
D: Great. I'll see you in a few weeks, Eli.
P: Okay, thanks, Dr. Patel.
</dialogue>

Deeply compassionate but occasionally shy in large groups, Ethan’s quirks—his impressive vocabulary and penchant for collecting bookmarks—make him memorable to friends and teachers alike. Though school often overwhelms him due to mounting homework and extracurricular obligations, Ethan finds solace in journaling, always striving to understand himself and the world around him better. He values honesty and loyalty, a trait taught by his parents’ emphasis on open communication, but sometimes struggles to voice his own needs, preferring instead to listen and help others with their troubles. Ethan’s favorite moments are quiet mornings spent reading before the rest of the house wakes up and the noise of the day begins.

Medical condition: seasonal allergic rhinitis (hay fever)

Reason for clinical visit: Ethan is visiting his pediatrician for a follow-up appointment regarding persistent allergy symptoms—sneezing, itchy eyes, and congestion—that have intensified since the start of spring.

<dialogue>
P: Hi, Doc. I've been feelin' pretty crummy for a while now. Sneezin' nonstop, my eyes feel like they're on fire, and I'm always stuffy.

D: Hi there, Ethan! It's great to see you. Let's take a look at what's going on. Can you tell me more about these symptoms? When did they start?

P: Um, I think it was around the beginning of spring. We had that big storm with all the pollen, and I just felt so miserable. My mom said it might be allergies, but I didn't think it was that bad.

D: I see. So, you've been experiencing these symptoms since spring started, and they've been getting worse?

P: Yeah, it's like my body just can't handle it. I feel like I'm always sneezing, and my eyes are all itchy and stuff.

D: Okay, Ethan. Let's take a look at your eyes. *examines eyes* Hmm, they do look a bit red and itchy. And your nose does seem a bit stuffy. Can you tell me more about what you've been taking for your symptoms?

P: Uh, just some Benadryl when my mom gives it to me. But it doesn't really help that much.

D: I see. Well, we can definitely work on finding something that will help alleviate your symptoms. In the meantime, I'd like to prescribe you something to help with your congestion and itching. *scribes prescription*

P: Awesome, thanks, Doc! I really appreciate it.

D: Of course, Ethan! Now, I want you to start using a saline rinse to help clear out your nasal passages, and we'll also talk about some other lifestyle changes that might help reduce your symptoms. Can you tell me about your daily routine? Do you have any pets or take any walks outside that might be exacerbating your allergies?

P: Oh, yeah! I have a dog, and I love taking him for walks. But I guess that might be making things worse.

D: Okay, we can work on finding ways to minimize your exposure to allergens. In the meantime, I want you to start using a HEPA filter in your room, and we'll also talk about some other ways to reduce your exposure to pollen. Sound good?

P: Yeah, that sounds like a plan. Thanks, Doc!

D: Of course, Ethan! I'm glad we could get you feeling better. Now, I want to schedule a follow-up appointment to check on your progress. How does next week sound?

P: Sounds good to me! Next week works perfect.

D: Great! I'll see you then. In the meantime, remember to take your meds as directed and use that saline rinse to help clear out your nasal passages. And don't forget to talk to your parents about getting that HEPA filter set up!

P: Will do, Doc! Thanks again!

D: Anytime, Ethan! Take care, and I'll see you soon!
</dialogue>

<dialogue>
P: Morning, doc. Thanks for seein' me.
D: Good morning, Gregory. It's been a while. How've you been feelin' lately?
P: Been alright, I reckon. Just gettin' a bit tired more often.
D: I see. Well, we'll get to that in a bit. Let's take a look at your blood sugar levels. How's your meter been readin' out?
P: Um, I think it's been around 180, 190. I don't know, I haven't been checkin' it as much lately.
D: Okay, that's a bit higher than we'd like. We need to get that under control. Have you been takin' your medication regularly?
P: Yeah, I've been tryin', but I haven't been perfect. Sometimes I forget.
D: Alright, well, let's work on gettin' that back on track. I'm also gonna prescribe you some metformin to help lower your sugar levels.
P: Sounds good, doc. I appreciate it.
D: Now, about these tinglin' sensations in your feet... when did you first notice 'em?
P: A few weeks ago, I think. Just a little numbness in my toes.
D: Hmm, that's not good. We need to get that checked out. I'm gonna send you to see a specialist, just to be sure.
P: Alright... okay.
D: Gregory, I want to make sure you understand the importance of managein' your diabetes. It's not just about your feet; it's about your whole body. We need to get your sugar levels under control and prevent any complications.
P: I know, doc. I'm tryin' to get it together.
D: I know you are, Gregory. But I need you to understand that this is a serious condition. We need to take it seriously.
P: I'll do better, I promise.
D: Alright, now, let's talk about your diet. What's been goin' on with your eating habits lately?
P: Uh, just the usual, I guess. Some days I do better than others.
D: Okay, well, let's work on gettin' you on a more regular routine. I'm gonna prescribe you some dietary supplements to help with your sugar control.
P: Sounds good, doc. I'll take care of it.
D: Now, I want you to make an appointment with the specialist I'm gonna send you to. We need to get those tinglin' sensations checked out.
P: Alright, I'll do it.
D: And one more thing, Gregory. I want you to start takin' care of yourself. You're not gettin' any younger, and we need to make sure you're takin' care of your health.
P: I will, doc. I'll do better.
D: Alright, now, let's get you set up with the specialist and get you on a regular routine. I'll see you at your next appointment.
P: Sounds good, doc. Thanks again.
D: You're welcome, Gregory. Take care of yourself, okay?
P: Will do, doc. I will.
D: Alright, that's all for today. I'll see you at your next appointment.
P: Sounds good, doc. Bye.
D: Bye, Gregory.
</dialogue>

<dialogue>
P: Hi, doc. Thanks for seein' me on short notice.
D: No problem, Gerald. What seems to be the issue? You said you were having some trouble sleeping and headaches?
P: Yeah. It's just...I don't know, I feel like I'm always on edge, ya know? And when I do finally get some sleep, I wake up feelin' like I've been hit by a truck.
D: I see. And how long has this been going on?
P: Long enough. I just...I don't know, I thought maybe I could, you know, just take care of it myself. Get more exercise, eat better, that kinda thing.
D: And have you been doin' that?
P: Yeah, I have. But it's just...it's not gettin' any better. I feel like I'm just gettin' more and more wound up.
D: I understand. Let's take a closer look. Can you tell me a bit more about these headaches?
P: They're just...they're just this constant pressure, ya know? Like someone's got a vise grip on my head.
D: And have you noticed any triggers? Like, do you get 'em when you're stressed, or when you're tired?
P: Yeah...I think it's when I'm stressed. I just feel like I'm always on the verge of losin' it, ya know?
D: I think we might need to explore some other options. Have you considered talkin' to a therapist?
P: I don't know...I don't know if I'm really comfortable with that.
D: It's just an idea, Gerald. Sometimes people find it helps to talk things through. But we can also look at medication. I think we might be able to find somethin' that can help with the anxiety.
P: Medication? I don't know...I've always been kinda hesitant about that.
D: I understand your concerns, but sometimes it's just what people need to get back on track. We can start with somethin' low-dose and see how it goes.
P: I guess...I guess it's worth a shot.
D: Okay, good. I'm gonna prescribe you somethin' and we'll go from there. We can also work on some other strategies to help you manage your stress and anxiety.
P: Alright...thanks, doc.
D: You're welcome, Gerald. Just take it one step at a time, okay?
P: Yeah...yeah, I will.
D: And don't hesitate to reach out if you need anythin' else.
P: I won't. Thanks again.
D: You're welcome. Take care, Gerald.
P: You too, doc.
</dialogue>

Biography: Richard Ellison is a 53-year-old man whose life is shaped by routine, caution, and deep concern for order. Having once served on active duty, Richard now works in a civilian role within national security, where he educates and trains colleagues—work he finds both meaningful and demanding. He lives with his long-term partner in a quiet, meticulously organized home; together, they enjoy a drama-free existence, rarely hosting guests, as Richard prefers solitude or the company of a select few. He spends evenings reading the news, reading up on international developments, or 'fixing' household electronics—often obsessing over minor malfunctions until everything's just so. Reserved and somewhat anxious in social settings, he prefers structure, routine, and predictability. Change unsettles him, and he sometimes has sleepless nights worrying about broader world events, as well as potential failures at work or lapses in his health routine. Though health-conscious, Richard's high-strung nature causes him to constantly monitor his well-being, sometimes to a fault. Reliability is his badge of honor—he takes pride in being dependable, though this can tip into rigidity. While not overly warm, he is straightforward and fair, occasionally struggling to express tenderness. He finds happiness in small, private successes: a finished book, a repaired device, a well-tended corner of his garden. But his high neuroticism means he is perpetually vigilant about threats—real or imagined—around him. His greatest strength is his discipline; his greatest weakness is his tendency to worry and withdraw. Despite this, Richard is loyal and principled, holding tightly to his convictions while navigating life with careful deliberation.

Medical condition: Generalized Anxiety Disorder

Reason for clinical visit: Richard is visiting his doctor today because he has been experiencing persistent insomnia, muscle tension, and trouble concentrating, largely due to ongoing worries about his health and job performance. <dialogue>
D: Hi Richard, thanks for coming in today. I understand you've been having some trouble sleeping and concentrating lately?
P: Yeah, I have. It's just...I don't know, I feel like I'm on edge all the time. Even when I'm doing things I love, like reading or gardening.
D: That sounds really tough. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on? When did you first start noticing these symptoms?
P: I don't know...months, maybe? It's just been building up. I've been having trouble falling asleep at night, and when I do, I wake up in the middle of the night and can't get back to sleep.
D: Have you noticed any triggers for these episodes? Anything that seems to set them off?
P: Yeah...it's just little things, really. Like, I'll be working on a project, and I'll worry that I'm not doing it right, or that I'm going to mess up. Or I'll be reading the news, and I'll see something about...about global events, and I'll just get this feeling of dread.
D: I see. It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety about performance and uncertainty. Have you tried any relaxation techniques to help manage those feelings?
P: I've tried...um...meditation, I guess. But it's hard for me to stick with it. I just get too caught up in my own thoughts.
D: That's okay. We can work on that. In the meantime, let's talk about some other strategies that might help. Have you considered keeping a journal to track your symptoms and identify patterns?
P: Yeah, I've thought about it. I just haven't gotten around to it yet.
D: Okay, well, let's make a plan to start doing that. I'll also prescribe you a medication to help with the anxiety. And I want to schedule a follow-up appointment for a few weeks from now to check in on your progress.
P: Okay...okay, that sounds good. I just feel like I'm losing control sometimes.
D: Richard, you're not losing control. You're just experiencing a normal response to a lot of stress. We can work with this. And remember, it's okay to not be okay. It's okay to ask for help.
P: Yeah...I guess you're right. I just need to...to learn to take things one step at a time, I think.
D: That's a great start. And we'll work on that together. Now, let's talk about some lifestyle changes that might help. Have you been exercising regularly?
P: I try to...um...walk a bit every day, but that's about it.
D: Okay, well, let's try to get you moving a bit more. Maybe we can schedule some physical activity for you to do each day. And I want to recommend some healthy eating habits to help manage your anxiety.
P: Okay, that sounds good. I just need to...to get my priorities straight, I think.
D: That's a great first step. And remember, you're not alone in this. We're going to work through this together.
P: Yeah...thank you, Doctor. Just talking to you makes me feel a bit better, I think.
D: That's what I'm here for. Now, let's get started on that journal, and we'll schedule that follow-up appointment for a few weeks from now.
P: Okay...okay, that sounds good.
D: And one more thing: have you considered talking to a therapist about your anxiety?
P: Um...I don't know...I've thought about it, but I've just never gotten around to it.
D: Okay, well, we can discuss that further at your follow-up appointment. But for now, let's just focus on getting you started with some strategies to manage your anxiety. Sound good?
P: Yeah...yeah, that sounds good.
</dialogue>

Patrick’s pride in his work is matched by a stubborn independence—he struggles to let others help and can be private to a fault, which sometimes leaves him feeling isolated. Despite a demanding job and occasional insomnia, he strives to stay active and connected with a small, trusted circle of friends. His wit and reliability make him a valued confidante, though he sometimes worries about his health, especially now that he’s starting to feel the effects of age: persistent joint pain in his knees that sometimes makes his beloved hikes less enjoyable.

Medical condition: osteoarthritis of the knees

Reason for clinical visit: Patrick is visiting his primary care physician to discuss worsening knee pain that has begun to affect his mobility and quality of life, particularly when gardening or hiking. He is seeking advice on pain management and possible interventions to maintain his activity level.

<dialogue_format>
P:...
D:...
P:...
D:...
</dialogue_format>

<dialogue>
P: So, Doc, I'm getting a little concerned about these knees of mine. Been having some issues lately.
D: Of course, Patrick. What kind of issues? More pain than usual?
P: Yeah, more pain than usual. Especially after I've been active. Gardening, hiking... you know, stuff I love to do.
D: I see. Have you noticed any swelling or redness?
P: Not really. Just the pain. And sometimes my knees feel a bit stiff in the morning.
D: Okay. Have you tried any over-the-counter pain relievers?
P: Yeah, I've been taking some ibuprofen, but it's not really doing the trick.
D: I'm not surprised. We can talk about prescription options, but first, let's get some baseline measurements. Can you stand up for me, Patrick?
P: Sure thing. (stands up)
D: Good. Now, can you bend down to touch your toes?
P: (bends down) Ow! Yeah, that's not easy.
D: I see. How about straightening up from that position?
P: (straightens up) A bit of a stretch, but manageable.
D: Okay. Now, let's talk about your pain. On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate it?
P: Hmm... probably a 6 or 7. It's not debilitating, but it's definitely there.
D: Alright. I'm going to order an X-ray to take a closer look at your knees. In the meantime, I want to prescribe some stronger pain relievers for you to try.
P: Sounds good to me. I just want to be able to keep doing what I love.
D: Of course, Patrick. We'll get you sorted out. But in the meantime, maybe consider taking it a bit easier on those knees. No more marathon hikes, okay?
P: (laughs) Alright, alright. I can live with that.
D: And I want to schedule a follow-up appointment for a few weeks from now to reassess your progress.
P: Sounds good to me. Thanks, Doc.
D: No problem, Patrick. We'll get your knees feeling better in no time.
P: (smiles) Appreciate it.
D: Now, let me just write out that prescription for you...
P: (chuckles) Take your time, Doc. I'm in no hurry.
D: (smiling) Alright. (scribbles on prescription pad) There we go. I'll also send a copy to your pharmacy.
P: Great. Thanks again, Doc.
D: No problem, Patrick. Just take care of yourself, okay?
P: Will do. (stands up, wincing slightly as he puts weight on his knees)
D: Patrick, can I ask you something?
P: Sure thing, Doc. What's up?
D: Have you considered talking to someone about your... (pauses, choosing words carefully)...your social isolation? You know, getting out more, meeting new people...
P: (looks taken aback) Oh, um... I don't know, Doc. I just... I like my routine, I guess. I don't really feel like I need to...
D: I understand, Patrick. But sometimes, just having someone to talk to can make a big difference. You don't have to be alone, okay?
P: (looks down, a hint of vulnerability in his expression) I... I'll think about it, Doc. Thanks for looking out for me.
D: That's all I can ask for, Patrick. Take care of yourself, and we'll catch up soon.
P: Will do. (nods, and the two shake hands before Patrick leaves the examination room)
</dialogue>
